question: America has made my fortune. I raised my daughter in the American fashion; I gave her freedom, but taught her never to dishonor her family. She found a boy friend, not an Italian. She went to the movies with him, stayed out late. Two months ago he took her for a drive, with another boy friend. They made her drink whiskey and then they tried to take advantage of her. She resisted; she kept her honor. So they beat her like an animal. When I went to the hospital her nose was broken, her jaw was shattered and held together by wire, and she could not even weep because of the pain. I went to the Police like a good American. These two boys were arrested and brought to trial. The judge sentenced them to three years in prison, and suspended the sentence. Suspended sentence! They went free that very day. I stood in the courtroom like a fool, and those bastards, they smiled at me. Then I said to my wife, for Justice, we must go to The Godfather.
answer: Bonasera, we know each other for years, but this is the first time you come to me for help. I don't remember the last time you invited me to your house for coffee...even though our wives are friends.

question: What do you want of me? I'll give you anything you want, but do what I ask!
answer: And what is that Bonasera? No. You ask for too much.

question: I ask for Justice.
answer: The Court gave you justice.

question: An eye for an eye!
answer: But your daughter is still alive.

question: Then make them suffer as she suffers. How much shall I pay you.
answer: You never think to protect yourself with real friends. You think it's enough to be an American. All right, the Police protects you, there are Courts of Law, so you don't need a friend like me. But now you come to me and say Don Corleone, you must give me justice. And you don't ask in respect or friendship. And you don't think to call me Godfather; instead you come to my house on the day my daughter is to be married and you ask me to do murder...for money.

question: America has been good to me...
answer: Then take the justice from the judge, the bitter with the sweet, Bonasera. But if you come to me with your friendship, your loyalty, then your enemies become my enemies, and then, believe me, they would fear you...

question: Be my friend.
answer: Good. From me you'll get Justice.

question: Godfather.
answer: Some day, and that day may never come, I would like to call upon you to do me a service in return. Where's Michael?

question: ...a fine boy from Sicily, captured by the American Army, and sent to New Jersey as a prisoner of war...
answer: Nazorine, my friend, tell me what I can do.

question: Now that the war is over, Enzo, this boy is being repatriated to Italy. And you see, Godfather... He...my daughter...they...
answer: You want him to stay in this country.

question: Godfather, you understand everything.
answer: Tom, what we need is an Act of Congress to allow Enzo to become a citizen.

question: Who do I give this job to?
answer: Not to one of our paisans...give it to a Jew Congressman in another district. Who else is on the list for today?

question: Francesco Nippi. His nephew has been refused parole. A bad case. His father worked with you in the freight yards when you were young. He's not on the list, but Luca Brasi wants to see you.
answer: Is it necessary?

question: I've never seen anything like it.
answer: I told you I had a lot of relatives.

question: Michael, what are those men doing?
answer: They're waiting to see my father.

question: They're talking to themselves.
answer: They're going to talk to my father, which means they're going to ask him for something, which means they better get it right.

question: Why do they bother him on a day like this?
answer: Because they know that no Sicilian will refuse a request on his daughter's wedding day.

question: Michael, that scarey guy...Is he a relative?
answer: No. His name is Luca Brasi. You wouldn't like him.

question: Who is he?
answer: You really want to know?

question: Yes. Tell me.
answer: You like spaghetti?

question: You know I love spaghetti.
answer: Then eat your spaghetti and I'll tell you a Luca Brasi story. Once upon a time, about fifteen years ago some people wanted to take over my father's olive oil business. They had Al Capone send some men in from Chicago to kill my father, and they almost did.

question: Al Capone!
answer: My Father sent Luca Brasi after them. He tied the two Capone men hand and foot, and stuffed small bath towels into their mouths. Then he took an ax, and chopped one man's feet off...

question: Michael...
answer: Then the legs at the knees...

question: Michael you're trying to scare me...
answer: Then the thighs where they joined the torso.

question: Michael, I don't want to hear anymore...
answer: Then Luca turned to the other man...

question: Michael, I love you.
answer: ...who out of sheer terror had swallowed the bath towel in his mouth and suffocated.

question: I never know when you're telling me the truth.
answer: I told you you wouldn't like him.

question: He's coming over here!
answer: Tom...Tom, I'd like you to meet Kay Adams.

question: How do you do.
answer: My brother, Tom Hagen.

question: I'm sure it's the most generous gift today.
answer: The Senator called--apologized for not coming personally, but said you'd understand. Also, some of the Judges...they've all sent gifts. And another call from Virgil Sollozzo. The action is narcotics. Sollozzo has contacts in Turkey for the poppy, in Sicily for the plants to process down to morphine or up to heroin. Also he has access to this country. He's coming to us for financial help, and some sort of immunity from the law. For that we get a piece of the action, I couldn't find out how much. Sollozzo is vouched for by the Tattaglia family, and they may have a piece of the action. They call Sollozzo the Turk. He's spent a lot of time in Turkey and is suppose to have a Turkish wife and kids. He's suppose to be very quick with the knife, or was, when he was younger. Only in matters of business and with some reasonable complaint. Also he has an American wife and three children and he is a good family man. He's his own boss, and very competent.

question: And with prison record.
answer: Two terms; one in Italy, one in the United States. He's known to the Government as a top narcotics man. That could be a plus for us; he could never get immunity to testify.

question: When did he call?
answer: This morning.

question: On a day like this. Consiglero, do you also have in your notes the the Turk made his living from Prostitution before the war, like the Tattaglias do now. Write that down before you forget it. The Turk will wait. What that? It sounds like Johnny. It is Johnny. He came all the way from California to be at the wedding.
answer: Should I bring him in.

question: No. Let the people enjoy him. You see? He is a good godson.
answer: It's been two years. He's probably in trouble again.

question: My Godson has come three thousand miles to do us honor and no one thinks to wet his throat.
answer: I kept trying to call you after my divorce and Tom always said you were busy. When I got the Wedding invitation I knew you weren't sore at me anymore, Godfather.

question: Can I do something for you still? You're not too rich, or too famous that I can't help you?
answer: I'm not rich anymore, Godfather, and...my career, I'm almost washed up...

question: ACT LIKE A MAN! By Christ in Heaven, is it possible you turned out no better than a Hollywood finocchio. All right, Hollywood...Now tell me about this Hollywood Pezzonovanta who won't let you work.
answer: He owns the studio. Just a month ago he bought the movie rights to this book, a best seller. And the main character is a guy just like me. I wouldn't even have to act, just be myself.

question: You take care of your family?
answer: Sure.

question: You look terrible. I want you to eat well, to rest. And spend time with your family. And then, at the end of the month, this big shot will give you the part you want.
answer: It's too late. All the contracts have been signed, they're almost ready to shoot.

question: I'll make him an offer he can't refuse. Now go back to the party and leave it to me. When does my daughter leave with her bridegroom?
answer: They'll cut the cake in a few minutes...leave right after that. Your new son-in-law, do we give him something important?

question: No, give him a living. But never let him know the family's business. What else, Tom?
answer: I've called the hospital; they've notified Consiglere Genco's family to come and wait. He won't last out the night.

question: Will your girl friend get back to the city all right?
answer: Tom said he'd take care of it.

question: What was this for?
answer: For bravery.

question: And this?
answer: For killing a man.

question: What miracles you do for strangers.
answer: I fought for my country. It was my choice.

question: And now, what do you choose to do?
answer: I'm going to finish school.

question: You should have told me your boss was Corleone, Tom, I had to check you out. I thought you were just some third rate hustler Johnny was running in to bluff me. Florence, thirteenth century. Decorated the garden of a king. I'm going to show you something beautiful. You like horses? I like horses, I love 'em. Beautiful, expensive Racehorses. Khartoum...Kartoum...You are looking at six hundred thousand dollars on four hoofs. I bet even Russian Czars never paid that kind of dough for a single horse. But I'm not going to race him I'm going to put him out to Stud.
answer: Mr. Corleone is Johnny's Godfather. That is very close, a very sacred religious relationship.

question: Okay, but just tell him this is one favor I can't give. But he should try me again on anything else.
answer: He never asks a second favor when he has been refused the first. Understood?

question: You smooth son of a bitch, let me lay it on the line for you, and your boss. Johnny Fontane never gets that movie. I don't care how many Dago, Guinea, wop Greaseball Goombahs come out of the woodwork!
answer: I'm German-Irish.

question: My business is heroin, I have poppy fields, laboratories in Narseilles and Sicily, ready to go into production. My importing methods are as safe as these things can be, about five per cent loss. The risk is nothing, the profits enormous.
answer: Why do you come to me? Why do I deserve your generosity?

question: I need two million dollars in cash...more important, I need a friend who has people in high places; a friend who can guarantee that if one of my employees be arrested, they would get only light sentences. Be my friend.
answer: What percentages for my family?

question: Thirty per cent. In the first year your share would be four million dollars; then it would go up.
answer: And what is the percentage of the Tattaglia family?

question: My compliments. I'll take care of them from my share.
answer: So. I receive 30 per cent just for finance and legal protection. No worries about operations, is that what you tell me?

question: If you think two million dollars in cash is just finance, I congratulate you Don Corleone.
answer: I said I would see you because I've heard you're a serious man, to be treated with respect... But I'll say no to you. I'll give you my reasons. I have many, many friends in Politics. But they wouldn't be so friendly if my business was narcotics instead of gambling. They think gambling is something like liquor, a harmless vice...and they think narcotics is dirty business. No...how a man makes his living is none of my business. But this proposition of yours is too risky. All the people in my family lived well the last ten years, I won't risk that out of greed.

question: Are you worried about security for your million?
answer: No.

question: We have something for your mother, for Sonny, we have the tie for Fredo and Tom Hagen gets the Reynolds pen...
answer: And what do you want for Christmas?

question: Just you.
answer: We'll have a quiet, civil ceremony at the City Hall, no big fuss, no family, just a couple of friends as witnesses.

question: What will your father say?
answer: As long as I tell him beforehand he won't object. He'll be hurt, but he won't object.

question: What time do they expect us?
answer: For dinner. Unless I call and tell them we're still in New Hampshire.

question: Michael.
answer: Then we can have dinner, see a show, and spend one more night. Operator. Get me

question: Michael, what are you doing?
answer: Shhh, you be the long distance operator. Here.

question: Hello...this is Long Distance. I have a call from New Hampshire. Mr. Michael Corleone. One moment please.
answer: Hello, Tom? Michael. Yeah... listen, we haven't left yet. I'm driving down to the city with Kay tomorrow morning. There's something important I want to tell the old man before Christmas. Will he be home tomorrow night?

question: Tell Paulie to get the car from the lot; I'll be ready to go home in a few minutes.
answer: I'll have to get it myself; Paulie called in sick this morning.

question: That's the third time this month. I think maybe you'd better get a healthier bodyguard for me. Tell Tom.
answer: Paulie's a good kid. If he's sick, he's sick. I don't mind getting the car.

question: Would you like me better if I were a nun?
answer: No.

question: Would you like me better if I were Ingrid Bergman? Michael?
answer: I'm thinking about it.

question: Michael...
answer: No, I would not like you better if you were Ingrid Bergman. They don't say if he's dead or alive.

question: Yeah. I think so. Detective squad? Is he alive? Find out anything you can...you got a Grand coming. Theresa, let me talk to Tom. Not yet? Have him call me as soon as he gets home. They shot the old man. Honey...don't worry. Nothing else is going to happen.
answer: You heard about your father?

question: Yeah.
answer: The word is out in the streets that he's dead.

question: Where the hell was Paulie, why wasn't he with the Don?
answer: Paulie's been a little sick all winter...he was home.

question: How many times did he stay home the last couple of months?
answer: Maybe three, four times. I always asked Freddie if he wanted another bodyguard, but he said no. Things have been so smooth the last ten years...

question: Go get Paulie, I don't care how sick he is. Pick him up yourself, and bring him to my father's house.
answer: That's all? Don't you want me to send some people over here?

question: No, just you and Paulie. A couple of our people will come to stay here. Do whatever they say; I'm going over to the main house. If you want me, use Pop's special phone. Hello.
answer: Santino Corleone?

question: Yeah.
answer: We have Tom Hagen. In about three hours he'll be released with our proposition. Don't do anything until you've heard what he has to say. You can only cause a lot of trouble. What's done is done. Don't lose that famous temper of yours.

question: I'll wait. Ma? Ma, where are you. Ma, I just got a call. Pop's hurt...I don't know how bad.
answer: Santino? Have they killed him?

question: We don't know yet, Ma.
answer: I'll get dressed. In case we can see him...

question: I know you're not in the muscle end of the family--so I don't want you to be afraid. I want you to help the Corleones and I want you to help me. Your boss is dead... Have some more. We got him outside his office, just before I picked you up. You have to make the peace between me and Santino. Sonny was hot for my deal, right? You know it's the smart thing to do, too. I want you to talk Sonny into it.
answer: Sonny will come after you with everything he's got.

question: That's going to be his first reaction. You have to talk some sense into him. The Tattaglia family stands behind me with all their people. The other New York Families will go along with anything that prevents a full scale war. The Don was slipping; in the old days I could never have gotten to him. Now he's dead, nothing can bring him back. Talk to Sonny, talk to the Caporegimes, Clemenza and Tessio...it's good business.
answer: Even Sonny won't be able to call off Luca Brasi.

question: I'll worry about Luca. You take care of Sonny and the other two kids.
answer: I'll try...It's what the Don would want us to do.

question: Thanks. You heard from Tom yet? C'mon.
answer: Don't worry, Theresa; they just want to give Tom the proposition, then they're going to turn him loose. I was worried when we couldn't get in touch with you in that hick town.

question: How's Mom?
answer: Good. She's been through it before. Me too. You were too young to know about it. You better wait outside; there're some things you shouldn't hear.

question: I can help you out...
answer: Oh no you can't, the old man'd be sore as hell if I let you get mixed up in this.

question: Jesus Christ, he's my father, Sonny.
answer: Theresa. All right, Mikey...who do we have to hit, Clemenza or Paulie?

question: What?
answer: One of them fingered the old man.

question: Clemenza? No, I don't believe it.
answer: You're right, kid, Clemenza is okay. It was Paulie.

question: How can you be sure?
answer: On the three days Paulie was sick this month, he got calls from a payphone across from the old man's building. We got people in the phone company. Thank God it was Paulie...we'll need Clemenza bad.

question: Is it going to be all-out war, like last time?
answer: Until the old man tells me different.

question: Then wait, Sonny. Talk to Pop.
answer: Sollozzo is a dead man, I don't care what it costs. I don't care if we have to fight all the five families in New York. The Tattaglia family's going to eat dirt. I don't care if we all go down together.

question: That's not how Pop would have played it.
answer: I know I'm not the man he was. But I'll tell you this and he'll tell you too. When it comes to real action, I can operate as good as anybody short range.

question: All right, Sonny. All right.
answer: Christ, if I could only contact Luca.

question: If I plead before the Supreme Court, I'll never do better than I did tonight with that Turk. Is the hospital covered?
answer: The cops have it locked in and I got my people there visiting Pop all the time. What about the hit list.

question: Too much, too far, too personal. The Don would consider this all purely a business dispute What about Luca? Sollozzo didn't seem worried about Luca. That worries me.
answer: If Luca sold out we're in real trouble.

question: Has anyone been able to get in touch with him?
answer: No, and I've been calling all night. Maybe he's shacked up.

question: Luca never sleeps over with a broad. He always goes home when he's through. Mike, keep ringing Luca's number. Keep trying every fifteen minutes.
answer: Tom, you're the Consigliere, what do we do if the old man dies?

question: Without your father's political contacts and personal influence, the Corleone family loses half its strength. Without your father, the other New York families might wind up supporting Sollozzo, and the Tattaglias just to make sure there isn't a long destructive war. The old days are over, this is 1946; nobody wants bloodshed anymore. If your father dies...make the deal, Sonny.
answer: That's easy to say; it's not your father.

question: I was as good a son to him as you or Mike.
answer: Oh Christ Tom, I didn't mean it that way.

question: We're all tired...
answer: OK, we sit tight until the old man can give us the lead. But Tom, I want you to stay inside the Mall. You too, Mike, no chances. Tessio, you hold your people in reserve, but have them nosing around the city. The hospital is yours; I want it tight, fool-proof, 24 hours a day. What is it?

question: The guy at the gate's outside...says there's a package...
answer: Tessio, see what it is.

question: You want me to hang around?
answer: Yeah. Hang around.

question: Crazy Detroit delivered it with a wooden bumper. They're going to send me the chrome bumpers in a couple months. I waited two years for this car to come with wooden bumpers! Today you make your bones on Paulie. You understand everything? .22 soft-nosed load. Accurate up to five feet.
answer: Rocco, sit on the other side. A big guy like you blocks my rearview mirror.

question: Goddamn Sonny. He's running scared. He's already thinking of going to the mattresses. We have to find a place on the West Side. Paulie, you know a good location?
answer: I'll think about it.

question: Drive while you thinking; I wanna get to the City this month! Pay attention!
answer: Good for ten men...

question: OK, go to Arthur Avenue; I'm suppose to call when I found somethin'. You wait; I'll call. He talked my ear off. Want us to go back to Long Beach; have another job for us. Rocco, you live in the City, can we drop you off? OK, then you gotta come back.
answer: You think we'll go for that last place?

question: Maybe, or you gotta know now.
answer: Holy cow, I don't gotta know nothing.

question: Hello. Kay?
answer: How is your father?

question: He'll be OK.
answer: I love you.

question: Yeah Kay, I'm here.
answer: Can you say it?

question: Huh?
answer: Tell me you love me.

question: I can't...
answer: Please say it.

question: Visiting hour ends at eight thirty. I'll just sit with him; I want to show respect.
answer: Can I go to the hospital with you?

question: I don't think so. You don't want to end up on page 3 of the Daily News.
answer: My parents don't read the Daily News. All right, if you think I shouldn't. I can't believe the things the papers are printing. I'm sure most of it's not true.

question: I don't think so either. I better go.
answer: When will I see you again?

question: I want you to go back to New Hampshire...think things over.
answer: When will I see you again?

question: Goodbye.
answer: Goodbye.

question: Hello? Hello?
answer: You're not supposed to be here now.

question: I'm Michael Corleone--this is my father. What happened to the detectives who were guarding him?
answer: Oh your father just had too many visitors. It interfered with the hospital service. The police came and made them all leave just ten minutes ago. But don't worry. I look in on him.

question: I won't panic.
answer: You cannot stay here...I'm sorry.

question: You and I are going to move my father right now...to another room on another floor...Can you disconnect those tubes so we can wheel the bed out?
answer: Absolutely not! We have to get permission from the Doctor.

question: You've read about my father in the papers. You've seen that no one's here to guard him. Now I've just gotten word that men are coming to this hospital to kill him. Believe me and help me.
answer: We don't have to disconnect them, we can wheel the stand with the bed.

question: Hurry, into there. Who is it? Enzo, get out of here. There's going to be trouble. Go outside; stand in front...I'll be out in a minute.
answer: He's awake.

question: Pop...Pop, it's me Michael. Shhhh, don't try to speak. There are men who are coming to try to kill you. But I'm with you...I'm with you now... Get rid of those and look like you've got a gun in your pocket. Listen...
answer: I thought I got all you guinea hoods locked up. Who the hell are you and what are you doing here?

question: What happened to the detectives who were supposed to be guarding my father?
answer: You punk-hood. Who the hell are you to tell me my business. I pulled them off. I don't care how many Dago gangsters kill each other. I wouldn't lift a finger to keep your old man from getting knocked off. Now get the hell out of here; get off this street you punk, and stay away from this hospital.

question: I'll stay until you put guards around my father's room.
answer: Phil, lock this punk up. Goddam it, I said lock him up. Put the cuffs on him.

question: The Turk wants to talk! The nerve of that son of a bitch! After he craps out last night he wants a meet.
answer: Was there a definite proposal?

question: Sure, he wants us to send Mike to meet him to hear his proposition. The promise is the deal will be so good we can't refuse.
answer: What about that Tattaglias? What will they do about Bruno?

question: Part of the deal
answer: We should hear what they have to say.

question: No, no Consiglere. Not this time. No more meetings, no more discussions, no more Sollozzo tricks. Give them one message
answer: The other families won't sit still for all out war.

question: Then THEY hand me Sollozzo.
answer: Come ON Sonny, your father wouldn't want to hear this. This is not a personal thing, this is Business.

question: And when they shot me father...
answer: Yes, even the shooting of your father was business, not personal...

question: No no, no more advice on how to patch it up Tom. You just help me win. Understood?
answer: I found out about this Captain McCluskey who broke Mike's jaw. He's definitely on Sollozzo's payroll, and for big money. McCluskey's agreed to be the Turk's bodyguard. What you have to understand is that while Sollozzo is guarded like this, he's invulnerable. Nobody has ever gunned down a New York Police Captain. Never. It would be disastrous. All the five families would come after you Sonny; the Corleone family would be outcasts; even the old man's political protection would run for cover. So just...take that into consideration.

question: Let's say now that we have to kill McCluskey. We'll clear that up through our Newspaper contacts later.
answer: Go on Mike.

question: They want me to go to the conference with Sollozzo. Set up the meeting for two days from now. Sonny, get our informers to find out where the meeting will be held. Insist it has to be a public place
answer: You? You, the high-class college kid. You never wanted to get mixed up in the family business. Now you wanta gun down a police Captain and the Turk just because you got slapped in the face. You're taking it personal, it's just business and he's taking it personal.

question: Sonny, it's all personal, and I learned it from him, the old man, the Godfather. He took my joining the Marines personal. I take Sollozzo trying to kill my father personal, and you know I'll kill them Sonny.
answer: It's as cold as they come, impossible to trace. Don't worry about prints Mike, I put a special tape on the trigger and butt. Here. Whatsamatter? Trigger too tight. I left it noisy, so it'll scare any pain-in-the-neck innocent bystander away. Just let your hand drop to your side, and let the gun slip out. Everybody will still think you got it. They'll be starin' at your face, see? Then walk out of the place real fast, but don't run. Don't look anybody directly in the eye, but don't look away from them neither. Hey, they'll be scared stiff o you, believe me. Nobody's gonna bother with you. Don't worry about nothing; you'd be surprised how good these things go. O.K., put your hat on, let's see how you look. Helps with identification. Mostly it gives witnesses an excuse to change their identification when we make them see the light. Then you take a long vacation and we catch the hell.

question: How bad will it be?
answer: Probably all the other families will line up against us. But, it's alright. These things have to happen once every ten years or so...gets rid of the bad blood. You gotta stop 'em at the beginning. Like they shoulda stopped Hitler at Munich, they shoulda never let him get away with that, they were just asking for big trouble...

question: Mike, they're gonna frisk you in the car. You'll be clean so they won't worry 'bout nothing. In the restaurant, wait and talk a while, and then ask permission to go. See? Then when you come out, don't waste time; don't sit down...you come out blasting. And don't take chances. In the head, two shots apiece. And out as fast as your legs can move.
answer: I want somebody very good, very safe to plant that gun. I don't want my brother coming out of that toilet with just his dick in his hand.

question: The gun will be there.
answer: You're on, kid...I'll square it with Mom your not seeing her before you left. And I'll get a message to your girl friend when I think the time is right.

question: Yeah. It's me, Sonny. Connie, what is it?
answer: It was my fault! I started a fight with him and I tried to hit him so he hit me. He didn't even try to hit me hard Sonny, I walked into it.

question: I'm goin' to have the doctor come over and take a look at you.
answer: Oh Sonny, please don't do anything. Please don't.

question: Kay, we weren't expecting you. You should call...
answer: I've tried calling and writing. I want to reach Michael.

question: Nobody knows where he is. We know he's all right, but that's all.
answer: What was that?

question: An accident. No one was hurt.
answer: Listen Tom, I let my cab go; can I come in to call another one?

question: Sure...I'm sorry.
answer: Will you give this to him.

question: Michael... It was Michael who killed Sollozzo. He's safe now...we're already working on ways to bring him back.
answer: We'll let the old man take it easy for a couple of weeks. I want to get things going good before he gets better. What's the matter with you?

question: You start operating, the five families will start their raids again. We're at a stalemate Sonny, your war is costing us a lot of money.
answer: No more stalemate Tom, we got the soldiers, we'll match them gun for gun if that's how they want it. They know me for what I am, Tom-- and they're scared of me.

question: Yes. That's true, you're getting a hell of a reputation.
answer: Well it's war! We might not be in this shape if we had a real war- time Consiglere, a Sicilian. Pop had Genco, who do I have? Hey Tom, hey...hey. It's Sunday, we're gonna have dinner. Don't be sore.

question: Who is this? You lousy tramp bitch.
answer: What was that?

question: Your girl friend. She says she can't make it tonight. You lousy bastard you have the nerve to give your whores my telephone number. I'll kill you, you bastard!
answer: You're crazy. She was kidding around; I don't know, some nut.

question: You're staying home. You're not going out.
answer: OK, OK. You gonna make me something to eat at least?

question: The food is on the table.
answer: I'm not hungry yet.

question: Eat it, it's on the table.
answer: Ba Fa Goulle.

question: BA FA GOULE YOU!
answer: You filthy guinea spoiled brat. Clean it up or I'll kick your head in.

question: Like hell I will.
answer: Clean it up! Even the female Corleones are murderers.

question: The baby! The baby!
answer: You're fat as a pig.

question: Go after him. This is Tom Hagen. I'm calling for Don Corleone, at his request.
answer: Yes, I understand. I'm listening.

question: You owe the Don a service. In one hour, not before, perhaps later, he will be at your funeral parlor to ask for your help. Be there to greet him. If you have any objections speak now, and I'll inform him.
answer: Anything...Anything the Godfather wishes.

question: Good. He never doubted you.
answer: The Don himself is coming to me tonight?

question: Yes.
answer: For the last year, they have been killing one another. So now, what? Your Godfather comes to me...Why? They've killed someone so important that they wish to make his body disappear. They could make me an accomplice to their murder. They could send me to jail! And if the other families find out...they will make me their enemy. They could come here to our house. I curse the day I ever went to the Godfather.

question: I want you to use all your powers, all your skill, as you love me. I do not want his mother to see him as he is.
answer: OK. Go to Clemenza's house and tell him to come here right away. He'll tell you what to do.

question: Give me a drop of anisette. My wife was weeping before she fell asleep, outside my window I saw my caporegimes to the house, and it is midnight. So, Consigliere of mine, I think you should tell your Don what everyone knows.
answer: I didn't tell Mama anything. I was about to come up and wake you and tell you. Just now.

question: But you needed a drink first.
answer: Yes.

question: Now you've had your drink.
answer: They shot Sonny on the Causeway. He's dead.

question: I want no inquiries made. No acts of vengeance. Consigliere, arrange a meeting with the heads of the five families...this war stops now. Call Bonasera...he will do me a service.
answer: This is Tom Hagen; I'm calling for Don Corleone, at his request.

question: You owe the Don a service. He has no doubt that you will repay it.
answer: I want to thank you all for coming. I consider it a service done to me personally and I am in the debt of each and every one of you. Especially those of you who have traveled from such distances as California, St. Louis, Kansas City; and New Orleans... Ah well, let's get down to business. We are all honorable men here, we don't have to give assurances as if we were lawyers. How did things ever go so far? Well, no matter. A lot of foolishness has come to pass. It was so unfortunate, so unnecessary. Tattaglia has lost a son; I have lost a son. We are quits. Let there be a peace... That is all I want... My friends, I didn't refuse out of malice. You all know me. When have I ever refused an accommodation? But why, this time? Because I think this drug business will destroy us in the years to come. It's not like whiskey or gambling or even women which most people want and is forbidden them by the pezzonovante of the Church and the Government. But drugs? No. Even policemen, who help us in gambling and other things would refuse to help us in drugs. But...I am willing to do whatever all of you think is necessary. I forego my vengeance for my dead son, for the common good. But I have selfish reasons. My youngest son had to flee, accused of Sollozzo's murder, and I must now make arrangements so that he can come home with safety, cleared of all those false charges. That is my affair, and I will make those arrangements. But I am a superstitious man...and so if some unlucky accident should befall my youngest son, if some police officer should accidentally shoot him, or if he should hang himself in his cell, or if my son is struck by a bolt of lightning, then I will blame some of the people here. That, I could never forgive, but...aside from that, let me swear by the souls of my Grandchildren that I will never be the one to break the peace we have made.

question: When I meet with Tattaglia's people; should I insist that all his drug middle-men be clean?
answer: Mention it, don't insist. Barzini is a man who will know that without being told.

question: You mean Tattaglia.
answer: Barzini.

question: He was the one behind Sollozzo?
answer: Tattaglia is a pimp. He could never have outfought Santino. But I wasn't sure until this day. No, it was Barzini all along.

question: Don Tommassino.
answer: Michael, why must you do this. We have been lucky so far, all these months you've been here we've kept your name a secret. It is from love for your father that I've asked you never to more than an hour from the Villa.

question: Calo and Fabrizzio are with me; nothing will happen.
answer: You must understand that your Father's enemies have friends in Palermo.

question: I know.
answer: Where are you going?

question: Corleone.
answer: There is nothing there. Not anymore.

question: I was told that my Grandfather was murdered on its main street; and his murderers came to kill my father there when he was twelve years old.
answer: Long ago. Now there is nothing

question: Don Tommassino...I should see this place.
answer: That is your birthright...but Michael, use this car.

question: No...I would like to walk to Corleone.
answer: Be careful Michael, don't let them know your name.

question: You tell us about America.
answer: How do you know I come from America?

question: We hear. We were told you were a Pezzonovanta...big shot.
answer: Only the son of a Pezzonovanta.

question: Hey America! Is she as rich as they say?
answer: Yes.

question: You can't hide it when you're hit by the thunderbolt. You know all the girls in this town, eh? We saw some beauties coming down the road. One in particular got our friend hit with the Thunderbolt...
answer: You had better bring a few bottles home with you, my friend; you'll need help sleeping tonight.

question: This one could seduce the devil. A body! and eyes as big and black as olives.
answer: I know about what you mean!

question: This was a beauty. Right, Calo?
answer: Beautiful all over, eh?

question: And hair. Black and curly, like a doll. And such a mouth.
answer: Yes, we have beautiful girls here... but virtuous.

question: Tell him to come to me. I understand I've offended you by talking about your daughter. I offer you my apologies, I'm a stranger in this country, I don't know the customs very well. Let me say this, I meant no disrespect to you or her...
answer: Who are you and what do you want from my daughter?

question: I am an American hiding in Sicily from the police of my country. My name is Michael. You can inform the police and make your fortune but then your daughter would lose a father rather than gain a husband. In any case, I want to meet your daughter. With your permission and under the supervision of your family. With all decorum. With all respect. I am an honorable man.
answer: Are you a friend of the friends?

question: It's safer to teach you English. Ciao, Don Tommassino. Things went badly in Palermo?
answer: The younger men have no respect. Things are changing; I don't know what will happen. Michael, because of the wedding, people now know your name.

question: Is that why there are more men on the walls?
answer: Even so, I don't think it is safe here anymore. I've made plans to move you to a villa near Siracuse. You must go right away.

question: What is it?
answer: Bad news from America. Your brother, Santino. He has been killed.

question: No, she's going home to her family. She'll join me in a few weeks...
answer: Should I get your bag?

question: No, I'll get it. Where's Appolonia?
answer: She is sitting in the driver's seat of the car, dying to step on the gas. She'll be a real American woman before she gets to America.

question: Tell Fabrizzio and wait for me in the car. Where the hell is he going? No. No! Fabrizzio. Let your shepherds know that the one who gives me Fabrizzio will own the finest pastures in Sicily.
answer: Be my son... This old building has seen its day. No way to do business...too small, too old. Have you thought about a wife? A family?

question: No.
answer: I understand, Michael. But you must make a family, you know.

question: I want children, I want a family. But I don't know when.
answer: Accept what's happened, Michael.

question: I could accept everything that's happened; I could accept it, but that I never had a choice. From the time I was born, you had laid this all out for me.
answer: No, I wanted other things for you.

question: You wanted me to be your son.
answer: Yes, but sons who would be professors, scientists, musicians...and grandchildren who could be, who knows, a Governor, a President even, nothing's impossible here in America.

question: Then why have I become a man like you?
answer: You are like me, we refuse to be fools, to be puppets dancing on a string pulled by other men. I hoped the time for guns and killing and massacres was over. That was my misfortune. That was your misfortune. I was hunted on the streets of Corleone when I was twelve years old because of who my father was. I had no choice.

question: A man has to choose what he will be. I believe that.
answer: What else do you believe in? Believe in a family. Can you believe in your country? Those Pezzonovante of the State who decide what we shall do with our lives? Who declare wars they wish us to fight in to protect what they own. Do you put your fate in the hands of men whose only talent is that they tricked a bloc of people to vote for them? Michael, in five years the Corleone family can be completely legitimate. Very difficult things have to happen to make that possible. I can't do them anymore, but you can, if you choose to. Believe in a family; believe in a Code of Honor, older and higher, believe in Roots that go back thousands of years into your Race. Make a family, Michael, and protect it. These are our affairs, sono cosa nostra, Governments only protect men who have their own individual power. Be one of those men...you have the choice.

question: There's a new one. Construction going on everywhere. That's one of the family's new ones. Not bad, eh?
answer: Why didn't Moe Green meet us at the airport?

question: He had business at the hotel, but he'll drop in for dinner. You look wonderful, kid; really wonderful. That doctor did some job on your face.
answer: You look good, too.

question: Nice, eh? Kid, take a look-see. Ever seen anything like that before?
answer: No.

question: Mike! The party starting!
answer: Come here a minute, Fredo. Who are those girls?

question: That's for you to find out.
answer: Give them some money and send them home.

question: Mike!
answer: Get rid of them... Johnny, the Corleone family is thinking of selling out all our interests in the Olive Oil business and settling here. Moe Greene will sell us his interest so it can be wholly owned by friends of the family.

question: Mike, you sure about Moe selling. He never mentioned it to me and he loves the business.
answer: I'll make him an offer he can't refuse. Johnny, the Don wants you to help us get started. We figure entertainment will be the big factor in drawing gamblers. We hope you'll sign a contract to appear five times a year for maybe a week long engagement. We hope your friends in the movies will do the same. We count on you to convince them.

question: Mike, good to see you. Got everything you want?
answer: Thanks.

question: The chef cooked for you special; the dancers will kick your tongue out and you credit is good! Draw chips for all these people so they can play on the house.
answer: Is my credit good enough to buy you out?

question: Buy me out?...
answer: The hotel, the casino. The Corleone family wants to buy you out.

question: The Corleone family wants to buy me out. I buy you out. You don't buy me out.
answer: Your casino loses money. Maybe we can do better.

question: You think I scam?
answer: You're unlucky.

question: You goddamn dagos. I do you a favor and take Freddie in when you're having a bad time, and then you try to push me out.
answer: You took Freddie in because the Corleone family bankrolled your casino. You and the Corleone family are evened out. This is for business; name your price.

question: The Corleone family don't have that kind of muscle anymore. The Godfather is sick. You're getting chased out of New York by Barzini and the other families, and you think you can find easier pickings here. I've talked to Barzini; I can make a deal with him and keep my hotel!
answer: Is that why you thought you could slap Freddie around in public?

question: Yeah sure. Sometimes I gotta kick asses to make this place run right. Freddie and I had a little argument and I had to straighten him out.
answer: You straightened my brother out?

question: Hell, he was banging cocktail waitresses two at a time. Players couldn't get a drink.
answer: I have to go back to New York tomorrow. Think of your price.

question: The Don has semi-retired. I'm running the Family business now. So anything you have to say, say it to me. Freddie, you're my older brother. I love you. But don't ever take sides with anybody against the Family again. I have to see my father and his people when we get back to the Mall.
answer: Oh Michael.

question: We'll go to the show tomorrow night--we can change the tickets.
answer: Don't you want dinner first?

question: No, you eat...don't wait up for me.
answer: Wake me up when you come to bed? Your sister wants to ask you something.

question: Let HER ask.
answer: She's afraid to. Michael... Why are you so cold to her and Carlo? They live with us on the Mall now, but you never get close to them.

question: I'm busy.
answer: Connie and Carlo want you to be godfather to their little boy. Will you?

question: Let me think about it, O.K.?
answer: Barzini's people chisel my territory and we do nothing about it. Pretty soon there won't be one place in Brooklyn I can hang my hat.

question: Just be patient.
answer: I'm not asking you for help, Mike. Just take off the handcuffs.

question: How did you find out?
answer: Bookkeepers know everything. Rocco's men are all a little too good for the jobs they're supposed to be doing. They get a little more money than the job's worth. Lampone's a good man; he's operating perfectly.

question: Not so perfectly if you noticed.
answer: Mike, why am I out?

question: You're not a wartime Consigliere. Things may get tough with the move we're trying.
answer: OK, but then I agree with Tessio. You're going about it all wrong; you're making the move out of weakness... Barzini's a wolf, and if he tears you apart, the other families won't come running to help the Corleones...

question: You're out, Tom. I'm going to talk to my father.
answer: I see you have your Luca Brasi.

question: I'll need him.
answer: There are men in this world who demand to be killed. They argue in gambling games; they jump out of their cars in a rage if someone so much as scratches their fender. These people wander through the streets calling out "Kill me, kill me." Luca Brasi was like that. And since he wasn't scared of death, and in fact, looked for it...I made him my weapon. Because I was the only person in the world that he truly hoped would not kill him. I think you have done the same with this man. Barzini will move against you first.

question: How?
answer: He will get in touch with you through someone you absolutely trust. That person will arrange a meeting, guarantee your safety... ...and at that meeting you will be assassinated. Your wife and children...you're happy with them?

question: Yes.
answer: Good.

question: I've always respected you...
answer: And I...you.

question: Christ, Tom; I needed more time with him. I really needed him.
answer: Did he give you his politicians?

question: Not all...I needed another four months and I would have had them all. I guess you've figured it all out?
answer: How will they come at you?

question: I know now. I'll make them call me Don.
answer: Have you agreed on a meeting?

question: Ephetha...be opened...So you may perceive the fragrance of God's sweetness. Do you renounce Satan.
answer: I do renounce him.

question: And all his works?
answer: I do renounce them.

question: Do you wish to be baptized?
answer: I do wish to be baptized.

question: You'd better make your call to Barzini; Michael's ready.
answer: We're on our way to Brooklyn. I hope Mike can get us a good deal tonight.

question: I'm sure he will.
answer: Hell, he can't do that. It screws up all my arrangements.

question: I can't go with you either, Tessio.
answer: Tell Mike it was business...I always liked him.

question: He understands that.
answer: Tom, can you get me off the hook? For old times' sake?

question: Godfather!
answer: You have to answer for Santino. You fingered Sonny for the Barzini people. That little farce you played out with my sister. Did Barzini kid you that would fool a Corleone?

question: I swear I'm innocent. I swear on the head of my children, I'm innocent. Mike, don't do this to me, please Mike, don't do this to me!
answer: Barzini is dead. So is Philip Tattaglia, so are Strachi, Cuneo and Moe Greene...I want to square all the family accounts tonight. So don't tell me you're innocent; admit what you did. Don't be frightened. Do you think I'd make my sister a widow? Do you think I'd make your children fatherless? After all, I'm Godfather to your son. No, your punishment is that you're out of the family business. I'm putting you on a plane to Vegas--and I want you to stay there. I'll send Connie an allowance, that's all. But don't keep saying you're innocent; it insults my intelligence and makes me angry. Who approached you, Tattaglia or Barzini?

question: Barzini.
answer: Good, good. Leave now; there's a car waiting to take you to the airport. I'll call your wife and tell her what flight you're on.

question: Good, good. Leave now; there's a car waiting to take you to the airport. I'll call your wife and tell her what flight you're on.
answer: You know I would never question anything you say.

question: Speak your mind.
answer: I'll do this for you; you know I should.

question: Michael!
answer: Connie...

question: You lousy bastard; you killed my husband...
answer: Connie...

question: You waited until our father died and nobody could stop you and you killed him, you killed him! You blamed him about Sonny, you always did, everybody did. But you never thought about me, never gave a damn about me. What am I going to do now, what am I going to do.
answer: Connie, how could you say such things?

question: Get her home and get a doctor. She's hysterical.
answer: Michael, it's not true. Please tell me.

question: Don't ask me.
answer: Tell me!

question: All right, this one time I'll let you ask about my affairs, one last time.
answer: Is it true?

question: No.
answer: We both need a drink.
